title: Optimizing Sleep
content: This text discusses optimizing sleep. It describes a pre-bedtime routine, the use of a sauna, and a regimen of medicines and supplements for improving sleep time and quality. It goes in depth on each of the molecules that have shown promise in boosting sleep, including their mechanisms of action as well as any noteworthy contraindications. It also discusses sleep wearables, including both the positives and potential negatives of using such trackers.

title: Pre-Bedtime Routine
content: The pre-bedtime routine consists of avoiding alcohol and eating too close to bed time, and using a sauna. Alcohol can reduce the quality of sleep, trading more deep sleep and REM sleep for light sleep, and causing more frequent wake ups. Eating too close to bed can negatively impact sleep quality. Using a sauna before bed can improve sleep quality.

title: Sauna Use
content: Sauna use can have benefits for sleep and potentially some mortality benefits. However, it is important to consider the individual's health, the opportunity cost of time spent in the sauna, and the financial cost of installing a sauna. The benefits need to be weighed against these factors. It is also noted that the literature is mostly on dry saunas, and it is unclear if infrared and dry have the same benefits.

title: Medications and Supplements for Sleep
content: Medications can enhance sleep through various mechanisms of action, but they should not replace good sleep habits. There are also sleep supplements that can enhance sleep, but their use should be considered in light of any contraindications.

title: Sleep Wearables
content: Sleep wearables can provide useful metrics for tracking sleep, but there are pros and cons to their use. They can help interpret sleep patterns, but there may be potential negatives associated with their use.

title: Importance of keeping an open mind as new information arrives
content: It comes down to what you anchor to: Do you anchor to being right or do you anchor to knowing the truth? If you can be more in the camp of the latter, it’s easier for you to accept change. Part of it is also understanding the nature of science and the scientific process: Even the best experiments don’t produce certainty, they just increase the probability of one idea being more likely than another. There really isn’t much that’s black and white in science — most things are shades of gray.

title: Importance of reducing stimulation leading up to bedtime
content: Anothing thing Peter focuses on is trying to be as unstimulated as possible before bed. For instance, he will floss and brush his teeth even before doing the sauna so that once he’s done with that sauna he goes straight to bed. He even goes as far as not going into the bathroom and turning the lights on. And he’s certainly not looking at his computer or phone. That’s probably another part of why this sauna is beneficial for Peter’s sleep — it could simply be that it’s a forced hour of bringing himself down as opposed to working right up until the last minute, brushing teeth, flossing teeth jumping in bed.

title: Medications that can enhance sleep: mechanisms of action, contraindications, risks, and Peter’s regimen
content: Peter takes 2 pharmaceutical agents and 3 supplements roughly 8.5 hours before he plans to wake up. Pharmaceutical agents/medications: 100 milligrams of a drug called Pregabalin, 50 milligrams of a drug called Trazodone. Supplements: 2 grams of a supplement called glycine, 600 milligrams of a supplement called ashwagandha, Two capsules, roughly 2 grams, of something called Magtein or magnesium L-threonate. Please note: Pregabalin is a Schedule V controlled substance due to its potential for respiratory depression. You should not combine Pregabalin with any other medications that can cause respiratory depression (such as benzodiazepines or opiates) and you should not drink alcohol while taking this medication.

title: Why medications can enhance sleep, but should not replace good sleep habits
content: Medications can enhance sleep quality and duration, but they should not replace good sleep habits. It's important to maintain a regular sleep schedule, avoid stimulating activities before bed, and create a sleep-friendly environment. Medications should be used under the guidance of a healthcare professional, and potential interactions with other medications should be considered.

title: Thoughts on Using Drugs/Supplements for Sleep
content: There are a lot of people who have big hiccups on this and they say, ‘Oh my god, that’s horrible. Why would you take a drug to sleep?’ And I would say if you feel that way, don’t. I don’t think it’s necessary. I mean, I sleep pretty well without those things. I just sleep a lot better with them. I don’t know why, but for some reason, and it’s understandable, I suspect people sort of think this is unnatural. We shouldn’t have to take anything to sleep. But I would argue we don’t necessarily live in a natural world anymore anyway. So I’m kind of looking for any advantage I can get.

title: Why One Should Not Use Drugs to Replace Good Sleep Habits
content: So someone who says, “I’m going to use these drugs but I’m going to short change sleep” is in for a painful surprise. Once you’re taking these, you’re committing to eight hours of sleep. If you’re going to only sleep 5 hours and you take these, you’re hosed because you’re going to be so drowsy the next day. Don’t look at these as hacks that you can use to shortchange all of the other stuff that we talk about with respect to hygiene and timing. These are truly accretive things that get added on and improve quality.

title: Sleep Supplements: Mechanisms of Action, Contraindications, and Regimen
content: Supplements taken regularly include Glycine (2 grams), Ashwagandha (600 milligrams), Magtein or magnesium L-threonate (Two capsules, roughly 2 grams). Supplements taken sparingly (e.g., for jet lag) include Phosphatidylserine and Melatonin. Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brainstem and spinal cord. In these areas, glycine inhibits motor activity during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. Patients who are taking clozapine shouldn’t be taking glycine. Ashwagandha is a milder version of phosphatidylserine. It reduces activation of the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal access and the cortisol release. An active ingredient of Ashwagandha leaves, triethylene glycol, can induce sleep in mice through reducing the NREM sleep onset latency period. During pregnancy and breast-feeding, in patients pre-surgery, in patients with stomach ulcers, autoimmune conditions, in patients on medication to manage diabetes, high blood pressure, or thyroid disorders, Ashwagandha should not be taken.

title: Melatonin and Sleep
content: Melatonin is probably the single most common sleep supplement out there. But it is not used regularly. How melatonin works: The pineal gland releases melatonin in the dark and melatonin therefore is a signal to the body that it is time to sleep. The increase of melatonin is a very important signal for our body to go to sleep. When we think about how much physiologic melatonin is secreted by the pineal gland, it’s a very small amount (20-100 micrograms). But when people take melatonin over the counter, it’s very hard to find a dose less than 1 milligram, which is 1,000 micrograms. But when you look at certain data, it would suggest that anything over 700 or 800 micrograms orally, tends to impact melatonin receptors in the brain by down regulating them. In other words, when you put so much of the molecule into place, the brain gets sort of desensitized to it and you reduce the receptors. Instead you want to work on ways to naturally create melatonin through light removal in the hours leading up to bed.

title: Magnesium L-threonate and Sleep
content: Magnesium L-threonate is a type of magnesium that can cross the blood brain barrier. When you take magnesium, it’s doing a bunch of great things in your body, but it’s generally not getting across the blood-brain barrier (so not getting into your brain). So the L-threonate is the transporter to the brain. Approximately 8 years ago, it was found that, in patients with early MCI (mild cognitive impairment), high doses of magnesium L-threonate were improving symptoms. The idea being that magnesium plays an important role in ion channel conductivity, including MDMA receptors, and something about getting more magnesium in the brain was improving neuronal health.

title: Temperature during Sleep, Cooling Devices, Mattresses, and More
content: Cooling devices/mattresses can be used to regulate temperature during sleep. One such device is the Eight Sleep, which allows you to set the mattress to different temperatures throughout the night. It also tracks your sleep staging (to the best an algorithm could). Weighted blankets, such as Gravity Blankets, can also be used, especially in the winter time. While the data on weighted blankets is sparse, anecdotally some people “feel insanely better with a weighted sleep blanket”.

title: Avoiding Back Strain in the Morning
content: A lot of people can hurt their back first thing in the morning when they just sort of lurch forward because you’re not warmed up and that puts a lot of strain on your back. A tip is to roll on your side towards the edge of the bed to where you’re in an “L shape”. Drop your legs off the side of the bed which should sort of lift you up naturally (could use a slight push with your arm). Basically get up sitting facing off the side of the bed.

title: Back Health
content: A seemingly healthy person can tweak their back getting out of bed too quickly or with a twist or a torque or doing something that’s otherwise kind of avoidable.

title: Polysomnography
content: A true polysom is not pleasant. You have to undergo it for a couple of nights because first night or two the data are so unhelpful because you’re not sleeping well because of all the wires you’re tied up to. The subject has leads on their chest that are measuring cardiac electricity, leads on their face that are measuring electricity, so they’re measuring the muscles of the eyes. Then they have all sorts of EEG leads on their scalp. What the scientist or sleep doctor is doing at the end of the night is looking at brainwaves, movement, and stages of sleep.

title: Sleep Trackers
content: Sleep trackers don’t directly measure sleep the way the polysomnography is attempting to. They’re not looking at brainwaves. There are some out there by the way, some headbands, that are trying to look at brainwaves but it’s TBD as to whether or not those things are going to be better than the wearables like Whoop and Oura. The three main variables that get measured by sleep trackers are: i) Movement, ii) heart rate and iii) heart rate variability.

title: Interpreting Metrics from Sleep Trackers
content: Most trackers will spit out an overall score of your sleep. But it's better to look at the raw inputs. For instance, resting heart rate, heart rate variability, body temperature. These are three objective measurements that can validate how you feel. Alcohol and lots of food will have the same thing, but not to that extent.

title: When a Wearable is Helpful and Not so Helpful
content: With sleep trackers, these things are really good in a couple of settings: 1 – when they allow you to tinker with changes that you’re making and assess the outcomes. 2 – The other area where it can be really helpful is in improving compliance of behaviors. It’s not so helpful when you cross over that threshold and you get into the point where the results of the thing, in this case the sleep tracker, if negative, impact your quality of life.

title: Final Takeaways on Sleep
content: You have to find the balance between the art and the science on this. Once you’re getting too bent out of shape over it, you’ve gone too far, you’ve got to back off and take the tracker off and stop micromanaging it. At the other end of the spectrum, a lot of people who sleep poorly, it’s really easy to fix if they’re really being brutally honest with their sleep hygiene stuff. Are you really stopping your food and your alcohol or cutting your alcohol all together at the right time? Are you really winding yourself down and not winding yourself up before bed? Are you in a dark room? Is it cool? And are you giving yourself 8.5 hours to be in bed?
